pageContext.desc: Narrative of an 1879 trip through the mountains of southern Colorado to Santa Fe, New Mexico.
pageContext.category: Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Collection; U.S. Western Expansion

pages.transcription:
From
Grassy Hill
To
Niegoldstown.
Wm. E. Strong.

Glimpses of Travel in the West
with the
Lieutenant General of the Army.

  It was my good fortune and privilege to 

make five trips through the Western States and Territories 
as the guest of Lieutenant General Sheridan
during the period that he was in command of the 
Military Division of the Missouri. 

  In February, 1878 to the Canadian and Cimarron  

rivers in the Indian Territory, by the way of Wichita
and Fort Reno, travelling on horse back with army
wagons and ambulances.

  In May and June 1879, through Southern 

Colorado to Pagosa Springs and Santa Fe New
Mexico. On horseback, with wagons and ambulances,

2.
from Forst Garland to the head waters of the Rio 
Grande river, via Alamosa, Del Norte, and Wagon Wheel
Gap, crossing the great divide from Grassy Hill Station
to Niegoldstown and Silverton, by the way of Stony
Pass, and from thence to Santa Fe via the Animas
Cañon, Animas City and Pagosa Springs.

  In July and August, 1880 to the Uncompahgre 

river in Colorado, travelling by rail to Pueblo and
Fort Garland, on horseback with wagons and ambulances
from Fort Garland to Surface Creek via
Alamosa, Del Norte, Sagnatch, Cochetopa Pass, Los
Pinos, Agency and the Uncompahgre river. From Surface
Creek returning to the railroad, at South Arkansas,
with General Mackenzie's pack train (eighty packs)
via Gunnison City and Marshal's Pass.

 In July, August and September, 1881 to the

Yellowstone National Park by the way of the
Union Pacific Railroad to Rock Creek Station -
from thence by ambulances and relays to Tongue
river by the way of Fort Fetterman, Powder river,

3.
and Fort McKinney - from thence to the National Park with Moore's famous train of one hundred and seventy five pack miles by the way of the Big Horn Mountains, Fort C.F. Smith and Clark's Fork. From the Park to Camas station on the Utah and Northern Railroad by the way of Henrys Lake, Henrys Fork, and Camas Prairie, and home by the Utah and Northern, and Union Pacific Railways.

  In the summer of 1882 to the National Park by the way of the Union Pacific Railroad to Green River - thence by ambulances and relays to Fort Washakie on Little Wind River - from thence to the Park on horseback with Moore's pack train following Wind River nearly to its source - thence westerly across the Wind River Mountains by Lincoln Pass to the Gros Ventre river - down the Gros Ventre to Snake river - up the Snake by the three great Tetons and Jackson Lake to Lewis Fork - up Lewis Fork, by Lewis Lake and Shoshone Lake, to the Upper Geyser Basin - from the Geyser Basin return-

4.
ing via Barronett's bridge, Cook City, Index Peak, North Fork of Clark's Fork, crossing the Bear Tooth Range of Mountains and decending its eastern face on a trail made by Mountain Sheep, striking finally, the western terminus of the Northern Pacific Railroad twelve miles west of Billings - thence to Bismark, Fargo, St. Paul and Chicago.

  These trips, the briefest possible outline of which I have given, are treasured in my memory as the most delightful experience of my life. I have but few memories of Europe or foreign travel but through the courtesy of General Sheridan and as his guest. I was privileged to look upon the grandest scenery America possesses, prehaps the World.
  The Cañons of the Arkansas, the Animas, the Gunnison, the Yellowstone. Have been to the summit of the Teton Range, and looked in admiration upon its lofty pinnacles reaching fourteen thousand feet toward Heaven, "robed in garments of untrodden snow." Three times have seen the Geysers of the

5.
National Park and three times have looked upon the Wonders of Wonderland from the heights of Washburn. Have crossed the "Switch back" over the Raton Mountains and ascended the Veta Pass on the pilot of an engine just as the sun was tipping the Western range, lighting up with magnificent effect the glistening domes of the Spanish Peaks. Have travelled for days among the lovely parks and glades of the Big Horn Range, ten thousand feet above the sea, and have watched the fleecy clouds drifting amid snowy peaks, and often hundreds of feet below, now obscuring and now revealing them - adding a vagueness and mystery to their shapes, which lent them an additional charm. Have seen flowers of rare beauty and in great variety growing luxuriantly by banks of snow and frozen brooks; groves which one might fancy the Dryads of Antiquity would love to haunt; streams that you look into in search of Arethusa; enchanted spots where Titania and Puck might come

6.
upon you unawares; waterfalls where the culprit Fay might strive to catch the drop as it fell from
the leaping sturgeon.

  I have selected for the subject of this paper the crossing of "Stony Pass" from Grassy Hill to Niegoldstown as being the most exciting incident connected with my travels with General Sheridan, and a description of which is best calculated to illustrate his perseverance, pluck and indomitable will.
  We left Chicago Monday morning May 19. 1879 by the Burlington and Quincy Road on a trip

to South Western Colorado and Northern New Mexico, the party consisting of the General, Colonel
M.V. Sheridan and Capt. James F. Gregory of his staff and Colonel Henry W. Farrar and myself.

  It was the General's purpose to go to Cañon City in order to see the Grand Cañon of the

Arkansas, through which the railroad had just been completed, then to Fort Garland by the way
of Pueblo. At Fort Garland we were to get our

7.
outfit of wagons, ambulances, riding horses, camp-equipment, etc. for a thirty days journey. The exact route from Fort Garland had been determined by the General before leaving Chicago and marked on his field map. He desired to follow the Rio Grande to its source crossing the mountains at Grassy Hill, visiting Silverton and other interesting points in the San Juan mining region, and thence to Santa Fé by the way of the Animas Cañon, Animas City, and Pagosa Springs. The information the 
General had received before leaving Chicago from the army officers at Garland and from reliable parties at Alamosa, Wagon Wheel Gap, Antelope Park, Lost Trail Station, and as high up as Grassy Hill, touching the condition of the roads and the practicability of crossing the mountains at that
season of the year was anything but encouraging. I saw the letters and dispatches. They were
from numerous sources - merchants, hunters, guides, packers - and the opinion was universally expressed,

8.
in the strongest possible language, that it was an utter impossibility to take any wagons and ambulances across the mountains at Grassy Hill, Lake  City, or at any of the other passes in May or June. It was reported that the snow lay to a great depth on the summit of the range - that the weather
was cold and snow storms were of almost daily occurence through the month of May - that no attempts  had been made to break a road for wagons at any of the crossings and that no attempts were likely to be made before July. The day we left Chicago while some of the party were commenting on the unfavorable reports which had been received, the General opened his map and putting his finger on the Rio Grande about Antelope Park, moved it quickly to a red line which had been drawn from Grassy Hill to Niegoldstown and said in a quiet tone "'we will cross there".

  On the twenty first at 4.30 P.M. we reached Pueblo. At 5. o'clock we left on the Pueblo and

9.
Arkansas Valley road (narrow gauge) for Cañon City, distant forty miles, making the run in an
hour and forty minutes.

  On the twenty second we had our breakfast at six o'clock and immediately after were conducted to a special train, provided for us by the coutesy of the Railroad authorities, and were soon off

to see 

The Royal Gorge
of the
Grand Cañon of the Arkansas.
We were accompanied by Mr. Scott, Superintendent of Construction, and Mr Clark Lipe of Chicago, the contractor for the building of the road through the Grand Cañon. The special train consisted of one open or flat car, which, in order to afford our party the best possible view, backed up through the Royal Gorge and  beyond it for several miles. The morning was bright and beautiful and the light breeze which prevailed carried directly away from us the smoke of the engine

10.
so that we had a clear and unobstructed view. We passed the Soda Springs and crossed a long stretch of level plain. For a mile or more we kept to the Valley and followed closely the smooth and placid tho' rapid waters of the Arkansas. As we proceeded the face of the country grew rougher and more broken, - the gently swelling knolls and ridges disappeared and formidable hills took their place which in turn gave way to towering mountains frowning above the Railroad track closely on either side gradually hemming in the waters of the Arkansas which now ran with swifter current and showed upon its surface ripples and patches of foam. Another half mile and we creep around the base of a magnificent granite cliff hundreds of feet high with sides almost vertical and coming squarely down to within a few feet of the waters edge, leaving barely room for the little narrow gauge track to pass it. Further on the changes were still more marked. Bold mountains rose up to great height on either side, with walls sloping backward and thickly dotted with a

11.
stunted growth of spruce and pine, and the river on our left leaped and foamed and sparkled in the early morning sunlight. Three-and-a-half miles from Cañon City we turned abruptly the base of a ragged precipitous spur from the main range, - a little valley lay at our feet and beyond loomed up in majestic grandeur, the lofty dead wall which marks the entrance to the Royal Gorge. Rapidly now we approached this marvelous cañon - this deep, dark and awful pathway of the Arkansas River through the heart of a solid
granite mountain. Before we fairly realized the fact we were past the gateway and were winding and twisting between the rugged walls of the mighty cañon of the Arkansas. So much has been written and published concerning this cañon and as my time is limited I omit any detailed description of it. No imagination however can conceive the superb panorama - the weird and grotesque forms amid these chasms of stone which seem ever crowding forward with an evil minded will to shut you in; "just a

12.
glimpse of blue sky far above such as miners see from the bottom of the black shaft"; while below to your left the wild river flowed narrower and fiercer over and around the rocks, taking on its mad career every possible form of cascade. Occasionally for a short stretch, the waters glide under the brown shadows of rock and bush, smooth, green and glassy,
but a moment later are torn into ribbons and scattered in glistening spray.

  The distance through the Grand Cañon by rail is eight - through the Royal Gorge four miles. We went as far as the Twelve mile Bridge and then returned to Cañon City.
  Mr. Clark Lipe, the principal contractor informed us that the work of grading through the Grand Cañon was begun October 1st, 1878 - that from that date to about May 1st, 1879. he had a force of from two hundred and fifty to three hundred men employed. The cost of grading and laying the rails through the Grand Cañon, about eight

13.
miles, was a trifle less than one hundred and forty thousand dollars to the mile. A great portionof the distance through the Grand Cañon the road bed had to be cut from a solid granite wall and much difficulty was experienced in getting a foot hold. Men, machinery and supplies were lowered from the cliffs to the bed of the river by means of ropes, and often a distance of from one thousand to fifteen hundred feet. We saw at several points the great snubbing posts still standing on the edge of precipices and although thirty inches in diameter and from forty to fifty feet in height appeared to us, even through strong field
glasses, not larger than ordinary fishing rods. It hardly seemed possible that men had ever been lowered to the bottom of the cañon from those heights.

  The Railroad bed through the cañon, and in fact of the entire line was equal to any I had ever seen. The work was skillfully and artistically done. The rails were of steel and the ties of oak. The grade averages fifty feet to the mile for about

14.
eight miles. The Arkansas averages from fifty to sixty feet in width and the bed of the Railroad lies from fifteen to twenty feet above it at high water.

  It was but a few months prior to our visit that the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad commenced operations in this cañon - opening for the Locomotive a pathway hitherto considered by the ablest engineers impracticable - in fact impossible. Until within a few months of our visit the dark recesses of this mighty gorge were unexplored except at one or two points near the entrance, which had been reached in midwinter. It was regarded as impossible to traverse it from the river level, except in the few cases on record, during winters of unusual severity, when the margins congealed to such a degree that by great caution and with the aid

of spiked boots and staves, a few adventurous spirits succeeded in penetrating a little way always in great peril of slipping toward the central current which never freezes. By the energy, enterprise and skill of

15.
a Railroad Company the difficulties were surmounted - the cañon was conquered, and from the platform of a palace car the traveler could see the wonders and beauties which for all time hitherto have been hidden from mortal eye.

  At nine o'clock we reached the depot at Cañon City; just in time for the Pueblo train. At eleven o'clock we arrived at Pueblo and at two-fifteen left on the Denver and Rio Grande Road for Fort Garland, distant ninety six miles. We passed through the

little villages of St Charles, Cucharas,Santa Clara, San Antonia, Bodito and La Veta, the latter lying at the foot of the Sangre-de-Cristo range over which the Railroad passed to Fort Garland, and from thence to Alamosa on the Rio Grande at that date the terminus of the road. After leaving Pueblo we skirted closely the base of the Greenhorn range and within two hours arrived at the junction with the branch road for Trinidad and El Moro; changing cars to reach those points. At St Charles

16.
we crossed the River of that name, and for a number of miles followed the general course of one of its tributaries, Greenhorn River, which we eventually crossed, as also further on Apachee Creek, a tributary of the Huerfano which flows into the Cucharas, a tributary of the Arkansas. For an hour and a half after leaving the junction we passed over a plains country wholly uncultivated so far as we could see save in the villages and adjoining them. As we approached the Mountains, after crossing the Greenhorn, the country became broken and hilly. Scattered here and there to the west of our route and between it and the foot hills we saw
vast numbers of round topped buttes. Approaching these we skirted the border of the fertile valley of the Arrapahoe which lies at the base of the Spanish Peaks whose symmetrical forms loom up grandly, the summit of one reaching an altitude of twelve
thousand, seven hundred and twenty feet, and of the other thirteen thousand, six hundred, and twenty

17.
feet. Fringing the banks of all the streams, and dotting the sides of the buttes and hills were piñon
trees.

  Ex. Governor Hunt of Colorado was a passenger on our train and we found him an interesting and agreeable traveling companion. He was at this time one of the most prominent men in the State and was the projector of the Denver and Rio

Grande Road and also very largely interested in it. He gave us a graphic history of the enterprise and the troubles and difficulties which had surrounded it. At about five o'clock the train pulled up at La Veta which is fourteen miles from the summit of the La Veta Pass.

  Governor Hunt invited General Sheridan, Colonel Farrar and myself to ride with him to the summit on the pilot of the locomotive, which invitation we gladly accepted. A couple of robes were spread for us on the narrow platform and we got comfortably and securely seated while wood and

18.
water were being taken aboard.

  The La Veta Pass ~

  In these days of progress there seem to be no natural difficulties which cannot be overcome by the energy and resources of the Railroad Engineer. The tactics of twenty years ago have been abandoned. The long detours to secure easy grades over Mountain passes are no longer considered economical in Railroad construction. The shortest and most direct route is the desirable and accepted one, no matter how high the pass, or how deep and inaccessible the cañon which bars the way. If it be Mountain Range it is approached by the shortest line, and the heavy grades are overcome by using locomotives of great power. Through the mountain or over it and never around it would seem to be the maxim of the Engineer. When the Union Pacific Railroad reached and crossed the backbone of the Continent at Sherman in eighteen hundred and sixty

19.
eight, at an elevation of over eight thousand feet, it was considered a marvelous feat in Railroad Engineering. Since then Railways have everywhere been built. Their links of iron and steel stretch out across a Continent, binding Ocean to Ocean, and tying State and Territory together in eternal Union - traversing broad plains and deserts - following the foaming rapids of the Arkansas through the dark and awful recesses of the Royal Gorge, climbing amid the clouds of Kenosha Summit on the Denver and South Park Road, at an altitude of more than ten thousand feet, or marking a pathway to the regions of perpetual snow, the La Veta Pass by the Spanish Peaks nine thousand, three hundred and thirty nine feet above the level of the sea. All these wonderful feats in railroad engineering, however, sank into insignificance when the Denver and Rio Grande Road extended its line into the San Juan mining region. The surveyed route crossing the range at an elevation of over twelve thousand feet and by grades hitherto believed

20.
to be impracticable. At the date of our trip the Summit of the La Veta Pass was the highest point reached by
any Railroad in North America.

  Wood and water were finally aboard - the bell rang - the whistle sent forth its warning scream,
  "The bright steel arms flew out and in" and we were off.
  The sun was just touching the crest of the Sangre- de-Cristo range as we pulled out of La Veta and  its rays streamed through the great rocky gateway - over the wooded slopes, spreading out to the valley below and upon the dense forests of pine, spruce and balsam which surrounded us on every hand - flashing across ridges and spurs to the South and resting upon the snow topped summits of the Spanish Peaks with a touch of light and glory. While life lasts I shall never forget the pleasure - the intense excitement of that ride. The evening was lovely, the air balmy and just enough breeze stirring to carry away from us the smoke and sparks from the engine.

21.
We were all in a mood to enjoy to the utmost this novel ride on the engine pilot. I sat on the right and at my side Colonel Farrar, next Governor Hunt, with General Sheridan on the left. I clung to the iron brace or support with my right hand and with my left over Colonel Farrar's shoulder aided him in keeping his seat. General Sheridan rendered similar aid to Governor Hunt. Slowly now but surely the engine creeps up, up, up, conquering foot by foot the tremendous grade. Soon after leaving La Veta the road makes a sharp bend round an isolated spur, then swings round the base of La Veta Mountain the altitude of which is eleven thousand, five hundred and twelve feet. The curve is a gentle one but the grade increases as we advance. For one-and-a-half miles we keep to this course, a ravine lying on our left hand through which courses Veta Creek. We twist in and out following the ravine clinging to its brink and at the same time hugging the mountain's side creeping up, up, ever up. The ravine grows deeper and deeper and the creek fades to a tiny thread and finally disappears. Now we swing sharply

22.
to the right, rounding the base of a bold bluff, then turning abruptly to the left creep along the southern base of Veta Mountain. The engine pants with labored breath and struggles desperately with the heavy grade all the time climbing higher and higher. - We sweep along at one point under the lee of a detached cliff, projecting spurs from which, hang over the Railroad bed. At another, the mountain wall rises vertically to great height bleak and bare. - And now we approach the grandest curve of all styled the "Mule Shoe Band" more than a mile in length. Straight ahead the road runs for half or three fourths of a mile, bordering the brink of the ravine which has now grown into a frightful chasm, and turning abruptly to the left around the head of it in a magnificent graceful curve leads directly back along the northern side of Dump Mountain forming a perfect horse shoe. This I think is one of the grandest points between La Veta and the summit. As we round the curve at the head pf the ravine passing from Veta Mountain to Dump Mountain the scene baffles description.

23.
The mountains close in on every side and the almost perpendicular wall is crowned by a heavy growth of trees whose shadows envelop us. Beneath and frightfully near, is the ravine which we have followed from La Veta, now a yawning abyss, seemingly bottomless. Down, down on either side, forests of spruce and pine cover the rocky side of the chasm. At one point we catch a glimpse of the old stage road which passes under the arch of stone round which bends the Mule Shoe. At Milk Ranch, Governor Hunt informed us, the grade is two hundred and seventeen feet to the mile; and here we got our first view of Inspiration Point, and the Railroad track was pointed out skirting the mountain's side nearly one thousand feet squarely above us and which we are told will require a full hour to reach.

  "The Mule Shoe crosses the viaduct over the stage road upon a thirty degree curve of one hundred and ninety three feet radius and is the sharpest

24.
railroad curve in the woods. The famous Horse Shoe Bend on the Pennsylvania Central road is a ninety degree curve of six hundred and thirty seven feet radius, while the greatest on the much vaunted Meiggs road over the Andes is a fourteen degree curve of three hundred and seventy six feet radius." An article, some years ago, in Scribners Magazine said "the ascent from Lima to San Bartolome, four thousand, nine hundred and ten feet in thirty nine miles was unparalleled in the history of railroad building"; yet the Denver and Rio Grande road reaches an elevation of twenty four hundred and thirty nine feet in fourteen miles - Veta to the Summit at an average grade of two hundred and  thirteen feet to the mile, while that of the Meiggs road is two hundred and ten feet to the mile.

  As we approach Inspiration Point the excitement of our wild ride increases. The scenery is of the most varied and striking character. We seem fairly suspended in mid air. Around and above us

25.
are crags and peaks, the clouds chasing wild shadows over their deep blue sides and the sunlight streaming over all. To the North and South, range above range of mountains crest, the grand and solemn "snow- crowned" summit of Mount Blanca lifts its peak "the nearest Heaven of any elevation on all the Continent". To the East, as far as the eye can reach, a  broad expanse of green verdure crowning great hilltops which come up like billows from the sea of mountains round about: then the "foot hills dropping away step by step like a grand staircase, to meet the plains which lie slumbering in quiet solitude below." The view was a constantly changing one from La Veta to the summit, increasing in grandeur as we proceeded, culminating at Inspiration Point.

  After leaving Inspiration Point we made numerous curves and windings around the mountain's side, and about dark the train pulled up at

26.
the summit, fourteen miles from the village of La Veta; twenty four hundred and thirty nine feet above it, and ninety three hundred and thirty nine feet above the sea. Captain Gregory's barometer read ninety two hundred and sixty five feet. We left the summit soon after dark, arriving at Garland at 8.30 o'clock. Major George Shorkley of the 15th. Infantry, commanding the post, met us at the station and conducted us to his quarters, which we found comfortable and attractive.

  Fort Garland lies on the eastern margin of San Louis Park, about eight thousand feet above the sea. It is located on a broad plateau and flanked on the North and East by high mountains. The scenery is unusually fine. Garland is a very old post. It was rebuilt however in 1861 by Kit Carson, who had command for several years. Some of the quarters were of adobe, but they seemed in an excellent state of preservation.
  On the morning of the 23rd after breakfast at the post, our camp equipage and baggage were loaded

27.
into wagons and ambulances, and we moved out a
mile or more and established camp on a level grassy
plat on the banks of a clear stream, - Ute Creek. The 
tents were pitched, mess chests and supplies overhauled,
and everything put in order for our trip which was
to begin the following morning. General Sheridan
was still determined, notwithstanding the unfavorable
reports, to follow the Rio Grande from Alamosa,
and to cross the mountains into the San Juan
mining region at Grassy Hill.

  After a lunch in camp we drove to the Fort

and passed a couple of hours pleasantly. We returned
to camp for dinner, which was served at
6 o'clock, Major Shorkley dining with us.

  After dinner a camp fire of piñon wood was

built before the General's tent, around which we
sat till a late hour, smoking and discussing our
proposed route and the prospects for hunting and
fishing.

  Our outfit for the trip was very complete.

28.
It consisted of three four-mule Army Wagons, one
six-mule Army Wagon and two four-mule ambulances.
An escort of fifty men from the 9th
Cavalry, under the command of Lieutenant John
F. Guilfoyle, and a small detail from the 15th
Infantry to pitch our camp, cut wood and do such
extra duty as might be required. Extra riding horses
were provided, fully equipped, for each member of the
party. The wagons, ambulances and teams came from
Fort Leavenworth especially for this trip. They were
in charge of the same Wagon Master who accompanied
us on our trip to the Canadian River in
January and February 1878.

  There were three new wall tents. One to be

occupied by General Sheridan, one by Colonel's
Sheridan and Farrar, and the other by Captain 
Gregory and myself. In addition we had a cook
tent, a large dining tent, and a sufficient number
of tents to accommodate the escort and the extra
detail of men. There were new mattresses, with

29.
heavy canvas covers, in which they were to be rolled
for packing, and upon which they were to be
spread at night - fine new mackinaw blankets, 
three pair for each bed with pillow and pillow
case for each mattress.

  The two mess chests of General Sheridan's

were made expressly for him in Chicago, after a pattern
belonging to General Drum, and had seen a good 
deal of hard service. They were used by the Secretary
of War in the Summer of 1875 on his trip to the
Yellowstone Park. Each chest was fifteen inches in
width, twenty four in length and eighteen in depth, and
weighed when packed sixty pounds. The two chests were
just a load for one mule, and on our trip from Fort
Ellis to the National Park and return, (above referred
to) a pack saddle was made expressly to carry 
them, one mule transporting them throughout the
entire trip over the roughest trail I have ever seen,
and without breaking a single article. Each chest
was provided with an outfit for six persons perfect

30.
and complete of its kind, having a full set of the 
finest crockery and glassware, knives, forks, spoons,
table linen, napkins, coffee and tea pots and coffee
and tea caddies. There were three movable trays in
each chest, every plate, cup, saucer, and goblet having
a compartment by itself, lined with some soft material
heavily padded. There was also a table with
adjustable legs which folded up compactly, occupying
but little space, and at which a dozen persons
could easily sit. There were also nine folding camp
chairs comfortable to sit in and which took up
but little room.

  The General brought along Mr. N.B. Smith,

an employee in the Quarter Masters Department at
Chicago, who was to have general charge of the
camp, baggage and supplies. With Charles to cook,
and Hackenjos to wait on us, nothing more could
be desired.

  On the twenty fourth of May we had our

breakfast at 6 o'clock and were off at seven.

31.
Our course was due West. Country almost a dead level,
and as far as the eye could see, covered with a heavy
growth of sage-brush. The escort under Lieutenant
Guilfoyl kept well in advance and we did not overtake
it until twenty minutes past ten o'clock at
Washington Springs twenty one miles from Garland.
Reached Alamosa, the terminus of the Railroad, at
eleven thirty A.M. and stopped long enough to purchase
forage for the command, and moving on
about seven miles encamped on the bank of the river,
having made thirty four miles. The wind blew
a hurricane after twelve o'clock, filling the air
with clouds of sand and dust. Our tents were pitched
with great difficulty, requiring the united efforts
of the entire force to keep them from being blown
away. The country traveled over was extremely uninteresting.
Between Fort Garland and Alamosa saw
but one small house, and that, occupied by a man
guarding a water tank on the Railroad. Nothing
but sand and sage brush along our route, In the

32.
distance could be seen the mountains bordering the
San Louis Park, many of them snow capped.

  On Friday the twenty fifth, we made forty 

miles encamping on the South Fork of the Rio 
Grande, fifteen miles from Del Norte.

  On Saturday the twenty sixth, made but

fifteen miles going into camp at Wagon Wheel Gap.

  On Sunday the twenty seventh made twenty 

six miles encamping at Antelope Park near
Galloway's Cabin.

  On Monday May twenty eighth, we pulled out

of camp at the usual hour. The road we traveled from
Galloways for a distance of twenty two miles, was
a new one, called the Antelope Park and Carrs Cabin
Toll Road. It was begun in the spring of eighteen
hundred and seventy eight, and was still in an unfinished
condition. We found it very rough and
dangerous and not at all practicable except for
strong wagons lightly loaded, and the best of
stock. Reached Lost Trail Station, eighteen miles

33.
from Galloways, at twenty minutes past eleven,
where we had lunch, and the General held a conversation
with the station keeper and a number
of packers who had just arrived from Silverton
with large burros pack trains coming in by the way
of Cunningham Pass. It was the opinion of all
these men that we could not cross by the Stony
Pass Trail with our heavily loaded wagons so
early in the season. The packers seemed much amused
at General Sheridan's attempt to cross the
range so early, and with such an outfit. They asserted
that we would all be back within two days.
We heard that the station keeper had ordered up
from Galloways an extra stock of forage to supply
us on our retreat from Stony Pass. Lost Trail Station
lies nine thousand, three hundred and sixty
feet above the sea. At twelve o'clock, our train
being closed up, we pushed on, and after travelling
four miles came to the terminus of the toll road
at Carrs Cabin. From this point the road was

34.
rougher and more difficult to travel than anything
we had yet seen. We struggled over it, however,
as best we could and at quarter before three
o'clock reached Grassy Hill Station. The distance
traveled was thirty two miles - the hardest days journey 
we had yet encountered. The wagons were not in
till six o'clock having been twelve hours on the road.

  From Galloways to Lost Trail Station the

scenery surpassed anything this side of Del Norte, -
but from Lost Trail to Grassy Hill, fourteen miles,
was grander than anything I had ever seen. The mountains
and cañons of the National Park, which I thought
unsurpassed, were nothing by comparison. We were
nearly up to the snow line at several points, - fairly
alongside the crags and peaks of the Mountain
Range which divided and seperated the Atlantic
and Pacific Slopes. I am unable to picture the dizzy
chasms which lay for miles along our wagon
road, or the shaggy breasts of the mountain cliffs
which rose about us. Five miles from Galloway's

35.
and just before crossing Pole Creek, from a great
height, we saw the Rio Grande divide, each branch
bearing away widely separated but heading for the
summit. The left branch we could see for a long
distance twisting and winding at the base of
the gigantic cliffs like a silver thread till finally
lost to view. We could truly say that we had been to
the very source of the Rio Grande, for within a 
few miles from the point where the stream divided,
both branches were created by the mountain
springs and the melting snows.

  Our tents were pitched close to the river and

within half a mile of Grassy Hill Station, which
was kept by a Mr. Watson. He came from Egypt,
Illinois to Del Norte in 1874, and to Grassy Hill 
in 1875. Owned a quarter section of land and had a
comfortable log cabin, which was said to be the
highest residence in the United States. Was interested
in packing over the mountains to Silverton.
Mr. Watson said we might possibly get over the

36.
Range with our wagons, but that it would be a 
terrible undertaking: the snow was deep - the road
unbroken, and snow storms were of daily occurence
on the summit at that season of the year.

  We had a rousing camp fire as usual and

around which we sat till about nine o'clock and
then retired.

  Tuesday, May twenty ninth, Calvert the

guide, Watson and myself, left camp immediately
after breakfast, and hunted all day for Mountain
Sheep - Rode down to Pole Creek - sent the horses
back by my orderly, and proceeded on foot. Hunted
along Pole Creek, and late in the afternoon followed
the summit of the main range back to Grassy
Hill. It was a hard days hunt. The altitude was
so great, that it was with difficulty we could
breathe. For several hours we were above the
timber line and traveling over the frozen crust
of the snow. We saw no sheep and but few signs
and no tracks that I thought were fresh. We

37.
struck the fresh trail of a grizzly and followed it
for more than two hours, but it finally led into
a cañon and we were forced to abandon it. We
were told by Mr. Watson that sheep were abundant
in this locality, and that a great number
had been killed during the previous winter. We
were not fortunate enough to see one, however.

  General Sheridan and the other officers with

all the men reconnoitered the road to the summit and
put it in as good order as possible. Had to shovel
snow in places, from seventy five to one hundred
yards. Snow was found to be from four to seven
feet deep. The party returned late in the afternoon
after a hard days work and the officers unite in
saying that they had never seen so difficult a road
to travel with loaded teams. General Sheridan
said we must cross, however if it took a month.
We would not retrace our steps. There were two trails
over the mountains from Grassy Hill to Niegoldstown
and Silverton: one via Cunningham Pass, which

38.
could be traveled only by pack animals, and the other
via Stony Pass, which was the wagon road. From
Watson's to Niegoldstown by the latter route is six
miles. The trail by Cunningham Pass is longer by
two and one half miles. It bears to the left from
the wagon road about a quarter of a mile from
Grassy Hill Station.

  We were to have a very early start on the

morning of May thirtieth, and had some hope
of making Niegoldstown by night; but if we
could get over the summit and make the timber
line would be content.

  About half past six snow began falling

quite briskly, and the wind swept down the
gorge from the mountains in terrible gusts. We sat
by the camp fire for an hour, but the wind blew
so fiercely that we finally withdrew to General
Sheridan's tent where we sat till eleven o'clock,
and then retired. At this hour the snow lay on the
ground several inches in depth, and was still

39.
falling.

  The Crossing at Stony Pass
                    from
  Grassy Hill to Niegoldstown.

  The morning of May thirtieth broke clear and

pleasant. Our breakfast was served promptly at half 
past five, just as the dawn came creeping over the
snowy crests which surrounded and shut us in. We
were in the saddle at a quarter past six o'clock,
and fifteen minutes later our train moved out of
camp. During the night the snow had fallen to the
depth of six inches.

  About a quarter of a mile from Watson's

cabin we commenced the ascent of Grassy Hill. The
road wound backwards and forwards around its
Southern base, zig-zagging, twisting, creeping up
higher and higher with the sharpest possible
curves. We were soon forced to dismount and advance

40.
carefully in single file, leading our horses. In many
places the road was very much tilted, and owing to the
new fallen snow, slippery; yet we managed to get over
it on foot with but little trouble. For the ambulances
and the heavily loaded wagons, however, it was no
easy task. Our wagon master, skillful and full of
expedients, and who seemed fully equal to any emergency,
took every possible precaution against accident
to the men and teams. One wagon at a time
passed over the difficult and dangerous portion
of the road, the others remaining near the foot
of the hill. Ropes were attached to the body of
each wagon, and at the side-hill places a dozen
or more men would be placed on the side above
the road, and by a strong pull on the ropes were
able to save the wagon from upsetting, although
at times it seemed as though it would go over
despite their efforts. At points along the route,
on the steepest grades, from fifty to seventy five
feet was all the distance that could be made with

41.
out a halt, to let the men rest and the mules
breathe. Whenever a stop was made, it was necessary
to instantly block every wheel with a boulder,
carried along by the men for that purpose. The
first stretch of troublesome road was over a mile
in length, and terminated at a cluster of abandoned
cabins, said to be one and a half miles from from Watson's.
By the united efforts of men and teams, the ambulances 
came up without doubling, but all the wagons had
to double, the two rear ones having fourteen mules
attached, and only making it then by the most
desperate efforts. It was an exciting experience 
and wholly new to me. Fourteen mules hitched to one
wagon, and struggling fiercely under the lash to
haul it up the almost vertical side of a mountain,
with a dozen men clinging to the wagon
by means of ropes, to prevent it from upsetting,
and as many more pushing at the wheels. Without
the aid of ropes and the strong force of men,
neither the ambulances nor wagons could have been

42.
dragged up this mile and a quarter stretch. At ten
o'clock the entire train had reached the level plateau
at the top of Grassy Hill, and was well closed
up. The orderlies had built a rousing fire in one
of the cabins, and another in the open air near by,
and the General resolved to wait here for a time,
to note what progress the teams made towards the
summit of the pass. If for any reason we failed
to reach it or the timber line beyond, he thought
we might be glad to return with the animals,
and occupy the cabins for the night. As there was
wood in abundance, all could be made comfortable.
At nine o'clock it commenced snowing very hard,
but within an hour it ceased and the sun shone
brightly. At a quarter past ten, our train had
passed the cabins and decended in safety the steep
pitch a few rods beyond. At the foot of this hill,
however, was a ravine, one hundred yards or more
in width, which was very soft. The ambulances
and three of the wagons crossed it without much

43.
trouble, but then, so badly was it cut up, the
rear wagon stalled and detained the train for half
an hour, requiring finally, twelve mules before
it could be moved. At eleven o'clock, the wagons
were closed up near the base of a hill, the steepest
yet encountered, though short. Soon after the
wagons had closed up at the foot of this hill, it
again commenced snowing. From our position at
the cabins, three fourths of a mile distant, we
watched through our glasses the movements of the
train. The snow fell fast, and at times we were
unable to see the wagons and teams distinctly.
The ambulances were taken up without doubling,
and three out of four of the wagons, with twelve
mules; but the rear wagon, which belonged to
the cavalry escort, and which was heavily loaded,
was stalled near the foot of the hill, and although
sixteen mules were hitched to it and the whole force
of men put at the wheels, they were unable to start
it. For three quarters of an hour, we watched through

44.
our glasses, the maneuvres of the wagon-master and
the men, in their efforts to start the wagon.
General Sheridan was nervous and impatient at the
delay, and finally, unable to stand it longer, mounted
his horse and telling us to follow, rode ahead
at a rapid pace. For ten or fifteen minutes after
the General reached the stalled wagon, he made
everybody fairly dance. The wagon-master's hands were
frozen, and he was completely discouraged, as were
the men, and presumably the mules. The wagon
was so heavily loaded, that double the number of
mules could not have hauled it up that hill.
When the General came up, the whole force was
ready to give up the ship. "Unload that wagon!"
said the General. "Throw off those tents! Pitch
out those grain sacks! Roll out that mess chest!"
I have seen wagons unloaded quickly, but never
before in my life did I see one stripped in so
short a time. "Now, go ahead with the wagon",
said he, "And you, men, carry those things to the

45.
top of the hill." The mules took the wagon straight
up without a halt, and in less than three quarters
of an hour, the men had carried the packages
to the hill top and reloaded the wagon. While
this was being done we had our lunch. At one
o'clock P.M. the train was ready to start, and we
were again pushing ahead. From this hour, the
whole command was hard at work, striving to
gain the timber line, beyond the summit, before
dark. Everybody worked with a will, and the
General took personal command. In my opinion,
no one but Sheridan could have kept that wagon
train in motion after two o'clock. He inspired
everyone with his energy, zeal, and unflagging
spirit. When he spoke the men took hold with
new life. At the sound of his voice, the mules
put forth, seemingly, renewed efforts. I do not
believe General Sheridan has had a better opportunity
to show his mettle since the war.

  After one o'clock, hill succeeded hill in

46.
quick succession, most of them very steep and
extremely difficult to pass. I can yet hardly
comprehend, how we got up and over some of
the trying grades which lay along our route.
Higher and higher we climbed, - doubling the
teams now at every hill, unloading the wagons
and lugging their contents up by hand. The altitude
was so great that we could breathe with difficulty,
and the animals seemed to suffer equally
with ourselves. Until one o'clock, the snow fell at
gusty intervals, but half an hour later, a terrific
snow storm came on accompanied by a strong
wind, increasing in fury as the afternoon wore
away, until it became a gale. It was frightful
beyond anything I ever experienced. The road, which
on the preceeding day had been cleared of snow
and ice to the summit by our men, was rapidly
filled, and outside of the deep cuts through
heavy snow banks, entirely obliterated, so that at
times we were off the trail, and out of our

47.
true course. Frequently, our route led us along the
brink of a cañon so deep that it made one dizzy
and sick to look down it, and we were often in
great danger of being swept over by the wind.
Before the blinding storm caught us, we could
see Mount Canby to the North of the Grand
Pass, or summit, and while this peak was in
sight, were in no danger of losing our true
course, but soon Canby and other adjoining
peaks which mark the gateway of this route,
were lost to view. We could scarcely see ten feet
ahead. The snow came down in sheets, - the 
flakes were icy, and cut ones hands and face
like hail, blinding and bewildering us so that
at times we were unable to face it. The wind
shrieked and howled across the summit, - sweeping
great clouds of snow and ice down upon
us from ledge and peak above, threatening to
bury us, or carry us off the cliffs into the
cañons. The cold was intense. I never suffered

48.
more. Both of my ears were frozen, and nearly
every member of the party was frost bitten.

  At two o'clock, and when the prospect of

our getting through seemed most discouraging, and
the storm was beating upon us with terrific fury,
shutting out from our view every land mark,
General Sheridan sent Colonel Farrar and Captain
Gregory ahead, with instructions to Lieutenant
Guilfoyle and his detachment to return at once and
help us with the wagons. Guilfoyle had been sent
forward from Grassy Hill, an hour in advance of
us with twenty men, provided with shovels, to
break roads through the snow drifts from the
summit to Niegoldstown, and the General thought
Farrar and Gregory would very likely overtake him
a mile or so beyond the summit. Without a
word, Farrar and Gregory put spurs to their horses
and galloped on, in execution of the General's
order.

  Hour after hour we struggled on through

49.
this storm, unparalleled in my experience, and over
a road the like of which I hope never to see again.
Occasionally, late in the afternoon, the sun burst
through the snow and clouds and mist, lighting
up the scene with magnificent effect. In these occasional
lulls in the storm, the view on every hand
was indescribably grand. Range and peak were
everywhere covered with snow. On our level, and below
us in the gorges and cañons, the snow clouds swept
by with lightening rapidity and for many hours we
were fairly enveloped in them. Never have I seen
anything so grand, so sublime; and notwithstanding
the discomforts of the day and the gloomy
outlook for the night, I enjoyed the experience.

  At half past six o'clock we gained the

summit of the Rocky Mountains, by the way
of Stony Pass, and the command was halted
abrest of Mount Canby. The wagons and ambulances
were now closed up compactly.

  At last we stood upon the broad snowy

50.
summit of the great dividing ridge, and among
the everlasting peaks, nearly fourteen thousand
(13,831) feet above the sea. Westward, within sight,
the melting snows swelled the mountain brooks
which flowed on to the Pacific Ocean; and behind
us, within easy rifle range, they feed the
tiny streams tributary to the Rio Grande, which
after a journey of more than three thousand
miles, finds the Gulf of Mexico at Bagdad. The
summit, or pass across the dividing ridge is
prehaps a quarter of a mile in width. The mountain
walls at this point are not precipitous, but
gentle slopes. Beyond these walls which mark the
pass rose rugged cliffs hundreds of feet above our
level. The view spread out before us, from the
summit, was grand and inspiriting, yet constantly
changing. One moment the sun pierced through
the drifting clouds around us, lifting the snowy
peaks from out their shadowy veils, and the
landscape glowed white and clear in the sunshine

51.

  The next moment storm clouds dark as

a funeral pall swept over the summit and
down the gorges, - the sun was hidden, darkness
and gloom surrounded us, the wind increased in
violence, and the icy sheets of hail and snow
again beat upon us with terrific fury.

  The night was fast approaching, and

men and animals were exhausted. The General
thought we had better encamp where we were,
although neither tree, bush nor twig were in
sight, as we were at least one and a half miles
above the timber line. No fires could be made,
of course, and the prospect for the night was
dismal enough.

  The wagon-master, in the mean time,

went ahead to reconnoitre, and upon his return
reported, that in his opinion it was not a mile
and a half to the timber. He was anxious to
go on, saying, he thought the teams could
make it by nine o'clock. The men also seemed

52.
desirous of pushing on to some point where wood
could be found, even though they were compelled
to work all night; so permission was given to
proceed. General Sheridan and myself went on to
look up a camp. We found the descent difficult.
Lieutenant Guilfoyle had cleared the road as well
as he could, in places cutting through snow banks
four to six feet in depth. We decended to the timber
line, which we estimated at a good mile and a
half from the summit, and selected a place to encamp
opposite the first tree, a pine, about four
inches in diameter. While we were working our
way down we saw, below, some one coming toward
us on foot. It proved to be Guilfoyle. He
reported that Colonel Farrar and Gregory had
comfortable quarters, and would not return
till morning. Guilfoyle had in obedience to the
General's instructions, cleared the road from the

53.
summit to Niegoldstown, barely reaching the
latter place, when Farrar and Gregory overtook
him with the orders to return at once. Although
completely worn out, he started back immediately
with his men, leaving his horses in the valley.
Guilfoyle said to me that he very much feared
his feet were frozen, and that he was nearly
dead; that he wouldn't repeat his experience of
that day for a Brigadier General's commission in
the Regular Army.

  After selecting our camp, I went back, by

the General's direction, to tell Colonel Sheridan
to push on with the train and make the timber
line, if possible. When darkness came on,
the train was over the summit, and down the
slope about half a mile, but men and teams
were now so completely worn out and discouraged,
that the General ordered the command
to encamp, which it was very glad to do, although
the prospects for the night were dreary enough,

54.
with no wood and no chance to pitch tents

  Colonel Sheridan and myself went down,

soon after dark to the camp we had selected.
The ambulances were brought down to within
five hundred yards of us. A tent fly and some
blankets were also sent down from the train
on a mule. Without removing our overcoats or
boots we wrapped ourselves up in blankets and
rolled ourselves up in blankets and
rolled ourselves in the tent fly and passed the
night as comfortably as possible under the
circumstances, though we had nothing to eat
but hard crackers and bacon.

  We were up by daylight on the morning

of May thirty first. Had supposed our difficulties
were substantially at an end when we gained
the summit, but we found the descent fully as
difficult and more dangerous. From the summit
to Niegoldstown the descent is very rapid,
thirty eight hundred and forty one feet in two
and a half miles. The greater portion of the

55.
distance from the timber line, is a succession of
steep pitches, over which wagons, loaded or light
can only be passed by means of snubbing ropes.
Some of these pitches are almost vertical. The
first, and the longest and worst one, was below
our camp some two hundred yards. It was called
Snubbing Post Hill. Early in the morning, Col.
Farrar and Capt. Gregory sent up from Niegoldstown,
a snubbing rope or cable which was
four hundred feet in length, and about two
inches in diameter.

  At nine o'clock our ambulances were lowered

at Snubbing Post Hill in safety, and all
the men were sent back to the main camp to
aid in getting the wagons down to the timber
line.

  The modus operandi in lowering wagons

by means of a snubbing rope, is substantially
as follows; one end of the rope is securely
fastened to the hind axle, all the wheels are

56.
"close locked", and but one span of mules is
hitched to the wagon. The rope is carefully
coiled near the snubbing post, which is from
fourteen to sixteen inches in diameter, and which
is located a few feet back from the crest of
the hill and quite close to the road. Two or three
turns of the rope are taken around the post,
and ten or twelve men are placed within fifteen
or twenty feet to handle it. Ropes are also
wound around the body of the wagon, and
from five to seven men stationed on each
side to steady it in its descent, and keep it from
upsetting. When all is ready, start the mules, -
tighten up on the side ropes, - loosen gradually
the coil about the post, and the wagon,
its load and the mules are lowered slowly,
surely, and with safety to the bottom. The
men who handle the snubbing rope, are
masters of the situation, - have perfect control
and can check the wagon at any point in its

57.
descent. Sometimes a wagon is let down too rapidly,
and a stream of smoke flies from the post
caused by the friction of the rope. We had a
man stationed near the snubbing post whose
duty it was to keep it deluged with snow to
prevent the ropes from catching fire.

  At twelve o'clock none of the wagons

had reached the timber line, nor were any of them
in sight.

  At nine o'clock the General went on to

Niegoldstown, leaving Colonel Sheridan to look
after the train, and I remained to keep the Colonel
company and aid him if required. It was found
necessary to make a new road, and one was consequently
cut out through snow banks from
five to seven feet in depth, and for a distance
of one hundred and twenty five feet. It was
finished at noon, and the train was at once
started. At half-past one o'clock, the wagons
were all closed up just below our camp of last

58.
night, and an hour's halt was ordered, to give
the men an opportunity to cook their breakfast
and make coffee. At half-past two, commenced
the descent of Snubbing Post Hill. The three four-
mule wagons were lowered in safety, but the six-
mule wagon was upset by careless handling
which detained us half an hour. As this wagon,
which belonged to the escort company, was moving
down to the crest of the hill and before it
reached the spot where the rope was to be attached
to the hind-axle, it got a start and shot
off from the road squarely to the right, and in
spite of the exertions of the driver and at least
fifteen men, who were holding on to the side
ropes and the locked wheels, it seemed for a
moment, that the whole outfit would certainly
go over the precipice. The teamster hung to his
reins with all his strength, and the darkies
clung to the ropes, being dragged for several
yards through the snow. At the critical moment

59.

  , when it seemed certain that wagon, team

and driver were lost, one of the darkies sang out
at the top of his voice "Hole on to de grub! Hole on
to de grub!". The men, seeming to appreciate the
great necessity for saving their supplies, amde
almost super-human exertions, and stopped the
wagon when the mules were within three
feet of the brink of the cañon. Everybody roared
with laughter at the exclamation, "Hole
on de grub!."

  From a point half a mile below Snubbing

Post Hill to Niegoldstown, was one long descent.
It was not necessary however at any point to
use the snubbing rope. The wheels were all
rough-locked and side-ropes were used, and it
was slow and difficult work to get the wagons
down. The last pitch, before reaching the
valley, was a full half mile in length, and it
required skill and the utmost caution to pass
it. We managed to get the ambulances through

60.
to Niegoldstown by six o'clock. At dark, however,
the wagons were still a quarter of a mile from
the top of the last hill, and full three-fourths
of a mile from the valley, and Col. Sheridan
directed them to encamp where they were.

  Colonel Farrar and Capt. Gregory had

found comfortable quarters at the stage station,
kept by one Simon Penrod, and had arranged
quarters for the balance of the party. We had
an excellent supper, and Mr. Penrod and his wife
did everything in their power to make us comfortable.
Our blankets were brought down from
the train and spread upon the floors of the
cabin and we had a good night's rest. Mr.
Penrod came to Niegoldstown from Denver in
1877, Served during the war in the First Pennsylvania
Cavalry, Gregg's Division, Sheridan's
command. Was badly wounded and had never
fully recovered his health.

  It was twelve o'clock, noon, on June

61.
first before the last wagon of our train reached
the valley near Penrod's house. In two and
one half days, therefore, our train had made
but six miles. Counting May twenty ninth,
the day of the reconnoissance from Grassy
Hill to the summit - and which was as hard
a days work as we had, and three and one
half days were required in making six miles.
Sunday evening June first we reached Silverton
and pitched our camp within one and a half
miles of that village, and near the entrance
to the Grand Cañon of the Animas.

  The Animas Cañon Toll Road was thirty

two miles in length and had cost over twenty
thousand dollars, and was not yet finished. It
was owned by a stock company. For many miles
the road was carved from the solid walls of the
cañon. The Animas River flowed through the
cañon, and the road clung closely to the stream.
Starting from the location of our camp, at the

62.
entrance to the cañon, the river falls one hundred
feet to the mile for two miles, - for the
next five miles, two hundred feet to the mile, - for
the next thirteen miles, one hundred feet to the
mile; and for the last twelve miles, two hundred
feet to the mile. The average fall from
Silverton to the head of the valley, or Animas 
Park, thirty two miles, is one hundred and fifty
feet per mile, or forty eight hundred feet for the
whole distance.

  Past our camp, the Animas River flowed

due South, and within a hundred yards, entered
a narrow gorge of rock, formed from the
walls of the Sultan and Kendall Mountains.
From our camp fire, at sunset, looking South
and following the general course of the stream,
along the banks of which our road ran, the
view was indescribably beautiful. The entrance 
to the gorge, or Grand Cañon of the Animas,
was rough, the ground being quite thickly

63.
covered with small pines. Further on, the walls
of the mountains bordering the Animas rose
higher and higher, covered with a mass of green
foliage, - ridge, pinnacle and peak, one above 
the other in rapid succession. Beyond, - further
to the South, were mountain summits, round-
topped and sharp, covered with snow and clearly
cut against the evening sky. Beyond all this,
in the dim distance, other mountains of snow,
the summits of which were lost in fleecy
drifting clouds. Directly North of our camp
was Boulder Mountain, upon the crest of
which the snow, apparently, lay to a great
depth, and at the base of which nestled the
quiet village of Silverton. Heavy black clouds
were sweeping swiftly over the Northern range,
but occasionally, the snow-capped peaks would
shine through, while every prominence reflected
the last lingering rays of the setting sun. I
have never yet in my travels seen anything more

64.
fascinating. High up the mountains, on every
hand, the snow had been falling at intervals
all day.

  As the General passed through Howardsville

and Silverton, salutes were fired in his 
honor and the people turned out en masse to
welcome him.

  From a Silverton paper "La Plata Miner"

of May thirty first, I clipped the following
notice:

  "Sheridan only Nine Miles Away".

"Lt. General Phil H. Sheridan, commanding the
"Military Division of the Missouri, with Head-
"Quarters at Chicago, will arrive in Silverton,
"accompanied by an escort, to-morrow. He has been
"between this place and Grassy Hill, sixteen miles
"away, since Thursday. With his train of five
"wagons, crossing the range via Stony Pass, he
"can hardly make the time made from Winchester
"down for he is still nine miles away".

65.

  "A delegation from Silverton have gone

"to meet the General and welcome him to Silverton
"and San Juan. Many of the buildings
"were decorated with flags, in honor of the
"coming of the bravest and most energetic officer
"in the service of our Country during the cival
"war".

  "The General will visit Pagosa Springs

"and the military posts in New Mexico and
"Arizona, before his return to Chicago".

  "The party consists of Genl. Sheridan, Genl.

"W.E. Strong, Colonel Henery W. Farrar, Colonel
"M.V. Sheridan and Capt. James F. Gregory."

  "The escort consists of a detail of cavalry

"under command of Lt. Guilfoyle. The wagons
"have been gotten over the range not without
"great difficulty, as they are the first that have
"crossed this season. They camped at Timber Line
"on this side, last night."

66.
Extract from my Daily Journal.
The Grand Canon of the Animas-Chain of
Lakes - Monday, June 2nd.

  We had a very early breakfast, and moved

out of camp on horse back, soon after six o'
clock. Made twenty five miles, and went into
camp at half past three P.M. The last of our
wagon train (six mule team) was not in until
five o'clock.

  We followed the Gand Canon for eighteen

miles. No words that I can command will 
fittingly describe it. I probably can convey
some idea of its beauty and grandeur, when
I say, unhesitatingly, that other cañons and
mountains seen by us on this trip dwindle into
insignificance in comparison with it.

  The walls of the Animas Cañon rise

twenty five hundred, three thousand, four thousand,
and at many points over five thousand
feet above the river and the road. Seven miles

67.
from our camp of last night we came to Elk Park,
where the cañon for a half a mile, widens out into
a beautiful valley, then narrows again, with higher,
steeper walls than before. As we enter Elk Park,
we see to the left a cluster of sharp, singular
looking peaks, which are known as Needle Mountains.
Some of these peaks are snow capped, while
others are bare and brown. After leaving Elk Park,
and for a distance of eleven miles, the cañon grew
deeper and darker at every step, - the walls higher
and higher, until one's eyes were fairly tired in
seeking their summits.

  There was every variety of scenery. For the

most part the cañon walls were not vertical,
but sloping, and covered with a dense growth
of spruce, balsam and quaking aspen. At points,
however, they rose squarely up on either side,
towering to the clouds, bleak and bare, with
overhanging crags black and blasted at their
summit, or bristling with stark and guarled

68.
pines threatening to topple over and crush us as
they stood out in bold releif against the sky,
resembling the high turrets of some ruined castle
that might be the hiding place of the winds.
Tiny streams, clear and cold, came bubbling out
of crevices in the rocks, and mountain brooks
poured over the rocky edges of precipices, so far
above us that the waters were mist and spray
long before reaching the level of the Animas.
Waterfalls, fed by springs, came leaping down
from rock to rock, forty, fifty, sixty feet at a
bound, finally rushing across our path, to the
river, with resistless current. Hundreds of feet
above us the waterfalls could be seen jumping
over a rocky barrier or apparently gushing
from a solid wall, "First, a silver thread; then a
"floating ribbon; then a wind-blown veil of spray".

  At our right for eight miles, then on our

left for ten miles, the Animas River rushed

69.
madly by us, over rock and boulder, in rapids and
falls, tossing its foam and spray high into the
air.

  After making eighteen miles, the road bore

off to the right and away from the river, to avoid
Cascade Cañon which is said to be grander
than anything seen by us to day; I am not
prepared to believe it. This cañon is considered
almost impassable, and comparatively few
persons have seen it. Soon after leaving the
river we came to a frightfully steep hill, over
two miles in length. It was a "breather" most
decidedly, but we finally conquered it. At points
in its ascent, the views of the surrounding country 
were lovely. Upon reaching the summit we 
had our lunch, gave the animals an hour's rest,
and then moved on four miles and encamped
at the lower end of a chain of lakes. Our camp
was a fine one. Calvert and I went out for deer.
We hunted faithfully for three hours, returning

70.
at half past six o'clock, but saw no deer, and 
but few signs.

  On Tuesday June third, we made twenty

five miles going into camp on the Rio Florido
(River of Flowers). Our days journey led us down
the beautiful valley of the Animas for thirteen
miles to Animas City.

  On Wednesday June fourth, we made

thirty three miles encamping on the Rio Piedra
(River of Stone), and on June fifth, after travelling
twenty two miles reached Pagosa Springs
where we remained for three days.

  Left Pagosa in the morning of June

eighth, - made twenty four miles and pitched
our tents on the Rio Navajo in New Mexico.
June ninth, encamped on the Chama. June tenth,
on the Conjilon. June eleventh, on the El Rito
and June twelfth, reached San Juan, one of the
villages of the Pueblo Indians, and late Friday
afternoon June thirteenth, arrived at Santa Fé.

71.
We left Santa Fé on our homeward journey Monday
morning June sixteenth, at seven o'clock.
Relays had been placed along our route, which
enabled us to make Los Vegas - seventy two miles
- at seven P.M. On the seventeenth of June at
twelve M. we reached the railroad where a
special train, with a Pullman Sleeper attached,
awaited us, and on Friday June twentieth at
three P.M. arrived home.

  I count it as the greatest honor and pleasure

of my life to have known General Sheridan,
and I cannot bring this paper to a close without 
expressing for him some words of tender regard,
and paying a tribute of respect to his memory.

  For many years he lived among us. Here he 

was married. Here his children were born. Here his
friends were numbered by the thousand, and as
strong and trusty and true as any he possessed
in life. With all that pertains to the growth,
the welfare, the prosperity of Chicago during

72.
his residence among us he was closely identified,
and ever stood ready to lend the influence of his
name and high position to advance the interests
of our city - to guard and protect our homes,
our property and our lives in every emergency
which arose.

  We all remember that fearful night more

than seventeen years ago, when the pitiless
whirlwind of flame swept over us and the genü
of the fiery tempest held high carnival. The
services rendered by General Sheridan during the
dark and trying days which followed; when
smouldering ruins marked the spot where our
proud city stood, will never be forgotten, and
with all the history and all the traditions of
Chicago his name should be, and will be, forevermore
inseparably linked.

  As we drift and drift along the current

of lifes journey, encountering day by day its
whirling eddies, its dangerous shoals, its

73.
treacherous quicksands, we learn to better appreciate
and more highly prize our friends - those
who have been tried in adversity, prehaps, and
whose friendship has been firm as the mountain
wall, steadfast as the needle to the pole
and carrying with it through sunshine and
through storm the ring and the gleam of gold.
Just such friendship as this, was General Sheridan's.
Stronger than mighty chains of steel, were the
invisible links which bound him to his friends.
Imperishable as the firmament was the love
they bore to him. Sweeter than the cunningest
strains of the musician or the wild melodies of
the harp are the recollections of our association
and companionship. Sacred, tender and beautiful
are the memories which lie treasured in our hearts
of his great deeds and heroic death.

  How sweet and gentle he was! How low

and soft and tender his voice! More like a
woman's voice than a man's. I have travelled

74.
thousands of miles with him on horseback and
in ambulances - spent days, weeks, months in
his company in Chicago, on Railway trains -
before the blazing camp-fires and around their
dying embers, and I never yet heard him speak
in a loud or boysterous tone. I never saw him
angry or excited. I never heard him swagger
or boast of anything he had done, and rarely
have I heard him speak of his services in the
war - never unless called out by urgent and
persistent appeals. Rarely have I heard him
utter one word that could not be repeated in
the presence of ladies. I do not say that he
did not on certain occasions during the war
use strong and vigorous language to fit the
case in hand - possibly swear some, and perhaps,
when he saw the stragglers and retreating troops
at Cedar Creek, October nineteenth, 1864. he did

  "Strike his spurs with a terrible oath.
  "And dash down the line mid a storm of huzzas"

75.
Though the General says in his Memoirs that
the language he used was

  "Face the other way boys, face the other

"way. If I had been here this disaster would
"not have happened. We will occupy our old
"camps to-night".

  But if he did utter that terrible oath

made historic by Thomas Buchanan Read we
now forgive him I am sure for we know that
"The wave of retreat checked its course there because
"The sight of the Master compelled it to pause".

  It has been said and it is unquestionably

true" that the mention of Sheridans name suggests
"all that has made our modern life masterful
" - directness, clearness, energy, daring and success".
In war he was like the wrath of God as the
psalmist invokes it for the destruction of his
enemies - quick, implacable, irresistable, coming
no man knows whence; bursting upon unprepared
heads with an invincible fury, striking where

76.
no man looks, and doing his work once for all
at a single stroke. His was not the slow
moving of the book tactician, but the impetuous
dash which sets all rules at defiance, and yet
he was always sure of himself; his quick
strokes were well poised and directed with a
terribly certain aim. "Push things" was the spirit
of his life, but he pushed intelligently and
with never a waste of energy.

  Busy memory recalls on this occasion

his marvellous record as a soldier and commander,
but its recital is unnecessary. That record in
minutest detail is known to every surviving
comrade and to every citizen in this dear land
of ours. His fame is secure - his appropriate
place in history has been assigned, and his rank
among the great generals of America and of
the world has been settled for all time by
one who loved and trusted him and under
whose command he fought and won his

77.
grandest victories - "Greater than Napolean,
great as Caesar" satisfies our hearts, and we
willingly leave his fame as a soldier where
Grant has placed it.

  While I cannot speak in detail of the

marches, battles and campaigns in which this
great soldier bore so conspicuous a part, yet
I may be pardoned if I refer briefly to the closing
scene of the great rebellion.

  Sherman had marched to the sea, and

through the Carolinas to Goldsboro. Grant
held Lee with an iron grip at Petersburg,
while Sheridan, after a thirty days march
from the Valley of the Shenandoah, was moving
into position on the left flank and rear
of the Army of the Potomac. The end of the
struggle for National Existence seemed approaching
and the heart of every soldier swelled
with joy in anticipation of soon being
released from the military service. Success and

78.
victory were everywhere crowning the Union Arms.
The soldiers were conscious that the end was near
and in their great joy thought only of the future
and the welcome muster out. Faces were wreathed
in smiles. The heart beat faster, the step
was lighter and stronger. What mattered it if
their marches had been long, their battles
desperate and bloody? What mattered it if their
feet had been blistered, their limbs weary,
their rations at times poor and scanty? Their
past hardships, privations and sufferings were but
a dream half forgotten. East and west along the
battle lines there stood, with glistening bayonets and
gleaming guns, 850,000 bronzed veterans. Victors
with not a thought of conquest. Warriors with
thoughts only of home and friends and loved ones.
In villages and great cities; in the forests and
on the prairies; in the palace of the millionaire
and in the humble home of the farmer and mechanic;
from the New England hills to the

79.
Golden Gate, everywhere throughout the land there
were loving, trustful, noble hearts waiting with
Spartan courage and heroism. Watching with
sleepless vigilance. Praying with a faith that never
wavered, with a fervor that never flagged for the
end of the war and for the sight once more of
the old familiar, loving face.

  March, twenty ninth, 1865 is at hand.

We bend our heads and listen. Muffled and
subdued by time, yet distinct and clear our ears
catch once more those memorable words from
the lips of our Great Commander of all the
armies. "By the left flank, March!" and from
their camps along the Weldon Railroad move
out that magnificent Cavalry Corps filing
through the woods, and down the country
roads in prompt obedience to the order. No
weighing, prancing steeds were theirs, richly
caparisoned. No glittering helmets - no nodding
plumes - no uniforms of scarlet and gold

80.
caught the eye, as nine thousand strong they
came near, passed by and disappeared on what
was destined to be their last campaign. In all
the history of the world there has been no
Cavalry Corps comparable to it. The Chivalry
of Spain in their palmiest days; Mago's
Numidian horse; Cromwells Ironsides; The
French Cavalry with Murat at its head; Lord
Cardigan's Light Brigade, were not its equal
in nerve, strength and powers of endurance - in
skill, courage and knightly gallantry. At
the head of this magnificent command and possessing
the confidence of every officer and man who
followed, rode a soldier short in statue, with
nothing superfluous about him, broad shouldered,
muscular, wiry to the last degree, as nearly insensible
to hardship and fatigue as is consistent
with humanity and weighing but one hundred
and seventeen pounds. A face much tanned by 
exposure, but lighted up by uncommonly keen

81.
eyes which would stamp him anywhere as a man
of quickness and force, while its whole character
would betray him to be a soldier, with its firm
thin, high cheek bones, and crisp moustache, and
this distinguished General was bound for Dinwiddie
Court House on the Boydton plank road and
bound to crush the rebellion so far as one man,
by precept and by example, could effect that desired
consummation and in twelve days he did
it in a series of victories unequalled in all history,
and to him in a high degree belonged the
credit and the glory of the achievement.

  Twenty three years the ninth of last April

since the guns were parked, the guidons folded tenderly
away at Appomattox Court House, and the hero
of that day, the hero of that hour, our friend
and companion, one whom we all loved and
who loved us lies forever at rest. Way in
advance of the battle lines - beyond the skir-

82.
mishers of that army of sixteen thousand heroic
dead. In sight of the broad Potomac, the Great
Monument, and the Nation's Capital, - in that
lovely spot rich with historic memories - the
sloping hill side at Arlington - amid the roar
of canon - valleys of musketry and the shrill
notes of the bugler's last call "Lights Out" - they
hid from sight, on that lovely August day but
just gone by, all that was left of the illustrious
soldier, the great commander Philip
H. Sheridan.

  Hail dear friend, and farewell! In all

the ages yet to come, thy countrymen will see
thy like no more.

  "His sword is rust,
   His good steed dust,
   His soul is with the saints we trust".
